title: 110_hr3844
content: The Act titled "Eradication of Slavery in Sudan Act of 2007" establishes the composition and structure. The "Eradication of Slavery in Sudan Act of 2007" establishes the United States Commission to Monitor Slavery and its Eradication in Sudan, composed of five members appointed by the President, Speaker of the House, majority leader of the Senate, minority leader of the House, and minority leader of the Senate. The United States Commission to Monitor Slavery and its Eradication in Sudan is composed of five members appointed by the President, Speaker of the House, majority leader of the Senate, minority leader of the House, and minority leader of the Senate. Members are selected based on their knowledge of Sudan, experience in relevant fields, and must obtain security clearances. Appointments must be made within 90 days of the enactment of the Act. The term of office for Commission members is three years, with eligibility for reappointment. The initial meeting must be held within 60 days of all appointments, where the Chair is elected by a majority vote. Subsequent meetings are called by the Chair or three voting members, with the Chair elected annually. The Commission members elect the Chair annually. The Chair, with input from members, hires an Executive Director within 60 days of the initial meeting. The Executive Director's duties include preparing a workplan, devising a budget, hiring staff, building relationships with organizations, and securing office space. The Commission members elect the Chair annually, who then hires an Executive Director. The President provides working space for the Commission at no cost. Members are allowed travel expenses while performing services for the Commission. The Commission is responsible for carrying out its duties as outlined in the legislation. The Commission's primary responsibilities include reporting on progress in identifying and freeing slaves in Sudan, ensuring their safe passage and reunification with families, documenting existing cases of slavery, preventing new cases, assessing needs of former slaves for education and support, and identifying and reporting on those responsible for slavery. The Commission is responsible for reviewing programs of relevant US Government agencies regarding slavery in Sudan and recommending actions to be taken in response to the Sudanese Government's inaction. They may hold hearings, take testimony, and receive evidence as necessary to carry out their duties. The Commission evaluates US Government policies on Sudan, recommends actions if Sudan fails to eradicate slavery, including diplomatic measures, protests, and sanctions. The Commission evaluates US Government policies on Sudan and recommends actions such as diplomatic measures, protests, sanctions, and withdrawal of the chief of mission in response to failure to eradicate slavery. The Commission must submit an annual report to the Secretary of State by October 1st detailing its efforts. The report may be classified, and members can include individual or dissenting views. The Federal Advisory Committee Act does not apply to the Commission. Authorization of appropriations is also addressed. Authorization of appropriations for the Commission is set at $1,500,000 for fiscal year 2008 and $2,000,000 for fiscal year 2009. These funds are available until the Commission terminates six years after all members are appointed.
